{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3327320,"name":"WarrenR","username":"warren.reynolds1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T23:03:25.515Z","cooked":"

Situation: Returning a frc2::CommandPtr from a Subsystem

If the returned CommandPTR is built using the FunctionalCommand like below

frc2::CommandPtr SubsystemName::DoSomethingCMD(){  
    return frc2::FunctionalCommand(
      [this] () {......},  //command's init
      [this] () {.....},   //command's Periodic 
      [this] (bool interrupted) {return .....},    //command's end
      [this] () {.....}    // commands's isFinished
     ).ToPtr();
}

Is there anyway to retain state information when the command is declared inline like this, without having to use a subsystem member variable?
IE like how commands can have their own member variables when you define a command as a class in it own file and you initialize the command’s member variable in the command’s init() and update them in the command’s periodic()

For example, if I want to count the iteration of the periodic loop of the command.

Cheers
Thanks for any advice.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T23:03:25.515Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"WarrenR","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50066,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3327333,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T23:15:07.618Z","cooked":"

All of those lambda functions have access to the class’s member variables and functions, since you passed in this to the capture. Therefore you can create state information as member variables of the class itself.

If you want to pass in e.g. a static local variable, you’ll have to explicitly include it in the capture. If you want these variables to only be used by the command then a local static variable might be better than using member variables.

However, if the command will be run in multiple places without cancelling (for whatever reason), you’re better off creating a local variable, capturing via copy (i.e. [a, b, c, this]). You’ll also need to set add mutable to the lambda.

Alternatively, if your command modifies the state of the subsystem itself, then just capture this and modify the member variables directly. I can’t remember off the top of my head if you need to add mutable to modify member variables.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T23:15:32.603Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":32,"readers_count":31,"score":11.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/2","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327336,"name":"WarrenR","username":"warren.reynolds1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T23:18:10.237Z","cooked":"
crueter:

as member variables of the class itself

Are you talking about the Subsystem class here?

Yeah; anytime I said class I’m referring to your subsystem as a whole.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T23:18:38.339Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":27,"readers_count":26,"score":10.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50066,"username":"warren.reynolds1","name":"WarrenR","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/4","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327347,"name":"WarrenR","username":"warren.reynolds1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T23:25:56.491Z","cooked":"

So, does this mean I can’t set a temp local variable in the First Lamdba of the FunctionalCommand ( the Commands Init) and then update this temp variable in the second lambda (ie the commands periodic) unless this variable exists outside of the functional command as a member variable of the subsystem class that owns CommandPtr returning method and this variable is captured.

I hope that question makes sense.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T23:27:17.121Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":26,"readers_count":25,"score":10.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"WarrenR","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50684,"username":"crueter","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50066,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327349,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T23:27:33.840Z","cooked":"
warren.reynolds1:

Is there anyway to retain state information when the command is declared inline like this, without having to use a subsystem member variable?

You have to have storage for that data somewhere. One way to share that data across multiple methods is to use std::shared_ptr and capture a copy of that shared_ptr into each lambda capture:

std::shared_ptr<int> val = std::make_shared<int>(0);
return frc2::FunctionalCommand(
   [val] { *val += 1; },
   [val] { *val -= 1; },
   ...
).ToPtr();

Note mutable isn’t required here because you’re not modifying the capture itself, but rather what it’s pointing to.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T23:29:38.949Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":23,"readers_count":22,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/6","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327352,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T23:28:48.942Z","cooked":"

You’re right that you can’t declare a local variable inside of the first lambda and use it later. However, you can declare a variable that’s local to the function itself, capture these by-copy in each lambda, and read/write to them at will (assuming you use mutable). @Peter_Johnson gave an example of what it would look like.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T23:28:48.942Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":22,"readers_count":21,"score":4.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50066,"username":"warren.reynolds1","name":"WarrenR","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/7","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327380,"name":"WarrenR","username":"warren.reynolds1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T00:11:02.085Z","cooked":"
Peter_Johnson:

std::shared_ptr<int> val = std::make_shared<int>(0);

Is this statement part of the code for

frc2::CommandPtr SubsystemName::DoSomethingCMD(){

What is the lifetime of this variable, do I have to worry about it going out of scope once the DoSomethingCMD method has returned its newly created Functional Command as a frc2::CommandPtr?

Or does this int live forever even though the shared pointer to it will be lost (I’m assuming once DoSomethingCMD returns we will loose it)

Should this shared pointer be deallocated in the commands end method to return the memory to the heap?

Sorry if these are dumb questions.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T00:11:02.085Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":18,"readers_count":17,"score":13.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"WarrenR","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50066,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327408,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T00:50:27.302Z","cooked":"

Yes, that shared_ptr variable is local to the method scope, and will be destroyed when the method has returned. However, the captures each make copies of the shared_ptr. All copies of the shared_ptr point to the same data (allocated on the heap). Internally, shared_ptr keeps a reference count of the number of copies (this reference count is also shared between all copies). Only when that reference count reaches zero is the underlying heap data destroyed. So as long as any of the captures are alive (which is done by the FunctionalCommand), the underlying data won’t be destroyed, despite the original shared_ptr variable going out of scope (that will just decrease the shared reference count by 1).

You can read more about shared_ptr here: std::shared_ptr - cppreference.com

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T00:58:42.321Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":18,"readers_count":17,"score":8.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/memory/shared_ptr","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"std::shared_ptr - cppreference.com","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50066,"username":"warren.reynolds1","name":"WarrenR","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/9","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327415,"name":"WarrenR","username":"warren.reynolds1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T01:04:16.112Z","cooked":"

So, if the CommandPtr command that was returned by DoDomethingCMD method of the subsystem is assigned to a member variable of the robot container, so that it can be put onto the dashboard to be run, this functionalcommand will effectively stay in scope for the lifetime of the robotcontainer object (basically forever)?

So does this mean that if this command runs and finishes from a click on the dashboard, then runs again with a another click on the dashboard, the int value will persist (ie whatever it was at the time the command ended from the first click, will be the same value the next time the command starts)?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T01:05:20.799Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":14,"readers_count":13,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457789,"topic_slug":"can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand","display_username":"WarrenR","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50066,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-make-a-command-member-variable-in-a-frc2-functionalcommand/457789/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327418,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T01:05:41.635Z","cooked":"

Yes and yes, just like if this was a Command class and you were using a member variable to store the int value.
